name: Security Monitoring
description: Security monitoring is your early warning system for detecting threats and understanding what's happening in your cloud environment. Before implementing monitoring for your Journal API, you need to understand logging, alerting, and monitoring fundamentals.

learning_steps.description: Start with your cloud provider's monitoring documentation:

• Authentication Logs: Who's logging in, when, and from where
• API Call Logs: What actions are being performed on your resources
• Network Logs: Traffic patterns and potential intrusions
• Application Logs: Your application's security-relevant events
• Infrastructure Logs: Changes to your cloud resources

learning_steps.action: Key Concept - Security Metrics to Track:
learning_steps.description:
• Failed authentication attempts
• Unusual API call patterns
• Network traffic anomalies
• Resource configuration changes
• Data access patterns

learning_steps.action: Key Concept - SIEM (Security Information and Event Management):
learning_steps.description:
• Collect: Gather logs from multiple sources
• Correlate: Find patterns across different log sources
• Alert: Notify when suspicious patterns are detected
• Investigate: Provide tools to analyze security events

• High Signal-to-Noise Ratio: Alerts should indicate real problems
• Actionable: Each alert should have a clear response procedure
• Escalation: Different severity levels with appropriate response times
• Context: Provide enough information to understand the issue

questions.prompt: Walk me through the types of logs you would collect for effective security monitoring in cloud environments.
scenario_seeds: Your security team needs to investigate a potential data breach that occurred last week. They ask what logs are available to reconstruct what happened. Walk through the different log types you'd need and what security-relevant information each provides.

You're setting up security monitoring for a new production environment running a containerized API with a managed database. Describe the logging strategy you'd implement to detect unauthorized access, configuration changes, and suspicious activity.

After a failed penetration test, the assessors noted that your logging was insufficient to detect their activities. They gained access through a compromised API key and moved laterally for two days undetected. What logs should have caught this?
questions.grading_rubric: Must identify multiple log categories (authentication, API/audit, network, application) AND explain what security events each captures AND mention cloud-specific services (CloudTrail, Activity Log, etc.) or equivalent concepts.

questions.prompt: How would you explain what a SIEM does to a colleague who has never used one?
scenario_seeds: Your company just purchased Azure Sentinel and your manager asks you to explain to the team why this is better than just looking at CloudWatch logs directly. Describe what a SIEM adds beyond basic log viewing.
A developer asks why the security team needs a SIEM when they can just set up CloudWatch alarms for specific error messages. Explain the difference between basic alerting and SIEM capabilities.

During an incident, you detected an attack by correlating failed SSH attempts from one source with successful API calls from the same IP five minutes later. Explain how a SIEM enabled this detection when individual log sources couldn't.
questions.grading_rubric: Must explain the four core SIEM functions (collect, correlate, analyze, alert) AND describe how correlation across multiple sources enables threat detection AND differentiate from basic logging/alerting solutions.

learning_objectives.text: Understand security monitoring concepts and tools
Know your cloud provider's monitoring capabilities
Understand logging and audit trail best practices
